#Text=4.
#Text=Optimal Tracking Control
#Text=A general scalar nonnegative attitude penalty function is utilized to formulate an optimal feedback control for the spacecraft tracking problem .
#Text=This new variable yields identical performance index values , regardless of the attitude variables selected .

#Text=The general final finite-time optimal control formulating is given by minimizing the following performance index : ( 79 ) which is subject to , where is the angular velocity error , is an arbitrary attitude representation of the attitude error , and the penalty functions are ( using and ) : ( 80 )
#Text=The weights and are scalars , and the weights , , and R are matrices .
#Text=The is the spacecraft error dynamics .
#Text=The scalar function is a general nonnegative attitude penalty function .
#Text=The function is chosen to produce the same cost for a given physical orientation : ( 81 )
#Text=when using exact nonlinear attitude error kinematics , the orientation will work for large angles ; .
#Text=Therefore , the function is bounded for all possible rotations .
#Text=Thus , the attitude cost reaches its highest value at the maximum rotation angle .
#Text=Defining the attitude cost function in terms of the DCM makes it universally valid for arbitrary choice of attitude coordinates .
#Text=It can be simply parameterized by any other attitude coordinate .
#Text=The universal quadratic penalty function for arbitrary attitude error representations is given in Table 3 .
#Text=This penalty function returns the same cost for a given physical attitude , thereby eliminating the dependency of the optimal control solution on the choice of the attitude coordinate .
#Text=4.1. Reference Angular Velocity Defined in the Body Attitude Frame
#Text=The reference and current angular velocities are expressed in the same coordinate frames ; i.e. , .
#Text=It can be shown that the general expression of the attitude error kinematics of this set can be given as follows : ( 82 ) with initial state .

#Text=The Hamiltonian H for this system of equations is defined , for the given optimal control problem in Equations ( 79 ) and ( 80 ) , as follows : ( 83 ) where and are the co-state variables for the angular velocity error and the attitude error , respectively .
#Text=Invoking the standard necessary condition for optimality , the co-state differential equations are given by the following : ( 84 )
#Text=The two co-state differential equations are integrated backward in time with given terminal values and .
#Text=The optimal control is given by the first-order necessary conditions for an extremum , , leading to .
#Text=4.2. Reference Angular Velocity Defined in the Reference Attitude Frame
#Text=The reference and current angular velocities are expressed in different coordinate frames , i.e. , .
#Text=Therefore , this definition explicitly computes the angular velocity error in the current body frame .
#Text=As an important result of this set , the expressions of the attitude error kinematics follow the attitude kinematics equation for any given attitude representation choice .
#Text=Therefore , the general expression of the attitude error kinematics of this set can be given as follows : ( 85 ) with initial state .
#Text=The Hamiltonian H for this system of equations is as follows : ( 86 )
#Text=Invoking the standard necessary condition for optimality , the co-state differential equations are given by the following : ( 87 )
#Text=The optimal control is given by the first-order necessary conditions for an extremum , , leading to .
#Text=Note the last term in the ( ) expression involves calculating the partial derivative of the angular velocity error kinematic , , which obviously leads to difficult math .
#Text=This step is also required when performing coordinate mapping between the DCM into other attitude parameters .
#Text=4.3. Numerical Simulation
#Text=This section presents simulation results of a fixed final-time and final-state open-loop optimal control solution for the spacecraft tracking problem .
#Text=Modified Rodrigues parameters are used for the attitude motion .
#Text=The initial and final state variable conditions for this example are given in Table 4 .
#Text=The spacecraft moment of inertia tensor is given in Table 5 .
#Text=For simplicity , the weighting matrices are , , , and .
#Text=However , one can sweep those penalties to obtain different solutions sets .
#Text=This example stands to solve the open-loop optimal control problem for the spacecraft tracking problem using arbitrary attitude representation .
#Text=We consider the universal performance index given in Table 3 .
#Text=The state and co-state differential equations are solved in a Boundary Value Problem ( BVP ) framework using a shooting method ( MATLAB fsolve ) .
#Text=The optimal open-loop solution is shown in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=.
#Text=The time history of the optimal trajectory and control is shown in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=a for MRPs representation .
#Text=The trajectory is controlled to drive the spacecraft for a given initial state error , and , to rest at zero attitude error after 25 seconds .
#Text=It is noted that the optimal open-loop solution obtained for various attitude representation produces the same angular displacement and total cost , as given in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=b.
